management_and_clinical_course: The initial management for the patient included oxygen administration, intravenous fluids, additional blood cultures, the administration of antibiotics (ceftriaxone 2 g and gentamicin 320 mg), a five-dose course of ivermectin (200 μg/kg/dose), application of topical scabicide every second day for the first week followed by twice weekly for the second week, and administration of a keratolytic cream after bathing on days when the topical scabicide was not used. The treatment outcome showed that the patient's blood pressure rose to 95 mmHg systolic, oxygen saturation increased to 97% with oxygen by nasal prongs, and she returned to the community health center where she received additional care including a wide-bore cannula insertion and an additional set of blood cultures. The blood culture taken in the community grew Staphylococcus aureus resistant to flucloxacillin and clindamycin but sensitive to gentamicin, co-trimoxazole, and doxycycline (i.e., community-acquired MRSA). The patient was managed in a single room with enhanced contact precautions, all family members were treated with topical permethrin 5%, and children with skin sores were each given a single dose of intramuscular benzathine penicillin. Clinical improvement included the patient being afebrile, off oxygen, and eating well, while family members followed up regularly by health staff to allow early diagnosis and treatment should she again be infected with scabies.
final_diagnosis: The final diagnosis is Crusted Scabies. Confirmation methods include positive skin scrapings under low-power magnification and clinical findings consistent with crusted scabies.
